docs.title: Welcome to RayforceDB
docs.text: The "another one" columnar database engineered to optimize your data analytics and storage solutions, ensuring a seamless, high-speed experience, which has:

docs.title: Existing features
docs.text:
• Simple LISP-like syntax

  • Columnar storage

  • SIMD-accelerated engine

  • Simple query language

  • No dependencies

  • Single binary with small size <1Mb directly fits in a CPU cache

  • Supports Linux, Windows, MacOS out of the box

docs.title: Incoming features
docs.text:
• Indexing

  • Compression

  • Paralleling

docs.title: IPC
docs.text:
Warning

For now it is unstable and possible subject of changes in the future!

A RayforceDB can communicate with other RayforceDBs via IPC. It is a very fast and efficient way of communication. It is used to send data between RayforceDBs, to send data to the client, and to send data to the server.

docs.title: Listen to a port
docs.text:
To start a Rayforce process that listens to a port, use the -p flag:

> rayforce -p 5110

docs.title: Connect to a remote process
docs.text:
To connect to a port call hopen function:

(set h (hopen "127.0.0.1:5110"))

Now, you can send data to the remote process:

> (write h "(+ 1 2)")
3
> (write h (list (+ 1 2)))
3

docs.title: Message format
docs.text:
There are two ways of sending ipc messages: string or list. In case of string it will be parsed an evaluated then, in case of list it will be evaluated as is.

Tip

Do not forget to call hclose for any unused connection handles!

(hclose h)

There are 3 types of messages:

  • Sync (request)
  • Response
  • Async

docs.title: Sync
docs.text:
Sync messages are used to send a request and get a response. Sync messages are blocking, so the sender will wait for the response.

> (write h "(+ 1 2)")
3

docs.title: Response
docs.text: Response messages are used to send a response to a sync message. Response messages are implicitly sent by the receiver of a sync message.

docs.title: Async
docs.text:
Async messages are used to send a message without waiting for a response. Async messages are not blocking, so the sender will not wait for the response. To send an async message, use negate for a connection handle with a write function:

> (write -h (list (+ 1 2)))

docs.title: Protocol
docs.text: The protocol is very simple. One just utilizes serialization to send/receive messages. Just one addition is: handshake. It is used to negotiate the protocol version and to send the credentials (if any).

docs.title: Handshake
docs.text:
After a client has opened a connection to a server, the first message sent by the client is a handshake message. It is a simple null-terminated ASCII string followed by a version number byte of next format: ["username:password"]v

Version is encoded as follows:

(RAYFORCE_MAJOR_VERSION << 3 | RAYFORCE_MINOR_VERSION)

docs.title: Add +
docs.text:
Makes an addition of it's arguments. Supports such types and their combinations: i64, I64, f64, F64, Timestamp.

> (+ 1 2)
3
> (+ 1.2 2.2)
3.4
> (+ 1 3.4)
4.4
> (+ [1 2 3] 3)
[4 5 6]
> (+ [1 2 3] 3.1)
[4.1 5.1 6.1]
> (+ 3.1 [1 2 3])
[4.1 5.1 6.1]

docs.title: Sub -
docs.text:
Makes a subtraction of it's arguments. Supports such types and their combinations: i64, I64, f64, F64, Timestamp.

> (- 1 2)
-1
> (- 1.2 2.2)
-1
> (- 1 3.4)
-2
> (- [1 2 3] 3)
[-2 -1 0]
> (- [1 2 3] 3.1)
[-2.1 -1.1 -0.1]
> (- 3.1 [1 2 3])
[2.1 1.1 0.1]

docs.title: Mul *
docs.text:
Makes a multiplication of it's arguments. Supports such types and their combinations: i64, I64, f64, F64.

> (* 1 2)
2
> (* 1.2 2.2)
2.64
> (* 1 3.4)
3.4
> (* [1 2 3] 3)
[3 6 9]
> (* [1 2 3] 3.1)
[3.1 6.2 9.3]
> (* 3.1 [1 2 3])
[3.1 6.2 9.3]

docs.title: Div /
docs.text:
Makes a division of it's arguments, takes a quotient. Supports such types and their combinations: i64, I64, f64, F64.

> (/ 1 2)
0
> (/ 1.2 2.2)
0
> (/ 1 3.4)
0
> (/ [1 2 3] 3)
[0 0 1]
> (/ [1 2 3] 2.1)
[0 0 1]
> (/ 3.1 [1 2 3])
[3 1 1]

docs.title: Mod %
docs.text:
Makes a division of it's arguments, takes a remainder. Supports such types and their combinations: i64, I64, f64, F64.

> (% 1 2)
1
> (% 1.2 2.2)
1
> (% 2 3.4)
2
> (% [1 2 3] 3)
[1 2 0]
> (% [1 2 3] 2.1)
[1 2 0]
> (% 3.1 [1 2 3])
[0 1 0]

docs.title: Sum sum
docs.text:
Makes a sum of it's argument. Supports such types: i64, I64, f64, F64.

> (sum 3)
3
> (sum [1.2 2.2 3.2])
6.6
> (sum [1 2 3])
6

docs.title: Serialization
docs.text:
Serialization is the process of converting nearly any Rayforce datatypes into a format suitable for storage or transmission, say: vector of bytes. This fundamental concept is integral to many software operations, from persisting object states to facilitating remote procedure calls.

Let's dive in.

Each serialized object starts from the 16-bytes header:

typedef struct header_t
{
u32_t prefix;
u8_t  version;
u8_t  flags;
u16_t reserved;
u64_t size;
} header_t;

Next, there is a type of the object. It's a single byte. Then, depending of the object type, there is a payload. For example, if the object is a vector, then there is i64_t length and a vector of atoms. If the object is a Dict or Table then there is a pair of keys and values. If the object is a function, then there is a string - source code of the function.

With this foundation, let's delve deeper into the world of serialization in Rayforce.
